title: Spooky action at the Hadron Collider; the milk of human kindness; and a cosmic goliath
description: LHC observes top quark entanglement; breastfeeding safe post-breast cancer; and astronomers spot largest pair of black hole jets.

title: Linnaeus’ taxonomy and the roots of scientific bias
description: His plant classification system, based on sexual characteristics, reinforced binary gender concepts and facilitated colonial botanical appropriation.

title: False memories: How they make us who we are
description: Memories shape our identity. The problem is that many of our memories are false. How can we know what is real or not?

title: Mini Moon Marvel
description: The mini moon is temporary and is, reportedly, quite rare as in most cases, asteroids either miss Earth or burn upon entering the atmosphere.

title: Starlink satellites are blinding astronomers’ view of space
description: These satellite networks are vital for giving high-speed internet to remote communities but unintended radiation leakages are troubling astronomers.

title: A decades-old virus resurges; Uncle Sam’s chip choke on China; and light-charged supercapacitors to spark an energy revolution
description: Chandipura virus claims 82 lives in India; US tightens tech exports to China; and IISc scientists unveil light-powered energy storage.

title: India’s climate strategy: Balancing growth with green commitments
description: Public-private-academic partnerships and strategic investments in key areas are crucial for India’s sustainable development pathway.

title: AI’s technological revolution: Promised land or a pipe dream?
description: Although billions are being invested in AI, the lack of marketable applications raises questions over a possible pay-off in the near future.

title: Why is a Fields medalist teaching math in war-torn Ukraine?
description: Efim Zelmanov’s foray into wartime education challenges the notion that scientists should stick to their formulas. Are Indian scientists listening?

title: AI spots five ways your grey matter goes grey; CERN’s search for new physics; Oxygen gives 2D materials a glow-up
description: Brains, beams, bright materials, and more in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: Pavel Durov’s free speech fight: Can Telegram survive its creator’s arrest?
description: The messaging app’s laissez-faire approach to moderation has attracted users and controversy alike. Now its founder faces legal troubles in France.

title: Is AI erasing our minds?
description: As digital assistants remember more, humans risk forgetting what makes us human.

title: Ocean floor breathes oxygen; Superconductors leap forward; Hepatitis C meets its DIY match
description: Seabed minerals produce ‘dark oxygen’; High-temp wires break records; and WHO approves first hep C self-test kit in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: Type 1 diabetes: Can ‘smart’ insulin provide a cure?
description: For people afflicted with T1D, “smart” insulin can help keep blood sugar levels stable.

title: WazirX: No one’s problem, everyone’s money
description: This brings us to the Finance Ministry in whose hands India’s crypto policy has largely been so far.

title: Youngsters do India proud at IMO 2024, pure sulphur found on Mars, and a blood test to detect cancer
description: India has its best outing yet at a maths olympiad; NASA’s Mars rover finds elemental sulphur on Mars; at last, a non-invasive test to detect cancer.

title: Nanako Hanada: The bookshop woman who refused to close the chapter
description: A Japanese memoir explores how literature can rescue a life in crisis.

title: The ocean is pumping oxygen from its abyss
description: How is the deep seabed, containing no photosynthetic organisms, releasing oxygen?

title: India needs climate justice, not just targets
description: Our climate vision demands a radical rethink: Balancing growth with sustainability while challenging global norms and pushing for equitable solutions.

title: Editor’s Note: We need a bigger, better heat action plan
description: As heatwaves intensify, India must scale up efforts to protect its vulnerable, boost climate resilience, and accelerate the shift to clean energy.

title: Omega Centauri’s black hole, record-energy neutrino, and GaN semiconductors for nuclear reactors
description: Evidence for central black hole in Omega Centauri; undersea telescope spots most energetic neutrino; GaN semiconductors to monitor nuclear reactors.

title: I do not think AI is a threat to human creativity: Meru Gokhale
description: Former editor-in-chief at Penguin Random House says her AI-assisted editing tool Editrix makes quality book editing accessible and affordable.

title: Vaccine side effects: Real but rare; blanket ban not the answer
description: Scientific studies are the key to improving vaccine safety and performance while acknowledging the tragic but infrequent adverse effects.

title: New climate model puts equity at the forefront
description: Researchers propose new framework for climate action that considers development levels, energy thresholds, and fair carbon budget allocation.

title: China bags moon dust from far side, top quark tips the scales, and the cosmic deuteron puzzle
description: Chang’e-6 mission brings home 2kg of lunar secrets; CERN teams up to nail down elusive particle’s mass; and how Deuterons defy expectations.

title: In this AI age, I still write my own articles
description: It seems ideal. A computer spits out text, you make a few corrections and you are done. But there are a few catches to AI that are not always obvious.

title: CERN’s funds crunch, new tech for nuclear fuel, and airborne pathogens get a new name
description: A new particle collider needs funds, a more efficient way to process irradiated nuclear fuel, and agreement on a common term for pathogens.

title: The Digital Competition Bill, 2024: What’s the fuss about?
description: The Bill is facing opposition from stakeholders as it permits CCI to intervene even before any harmful competitive practice takes place.

title: Asteroids and comets: What’s the difference?
description: We watch comets with wonder when they fly by Earth. But when asteroids like 2024 MK fly across our orbit, we track them with fear. Here is why.

title: A 400-year-old solar mystery, mass-producing recombinant proteins, and safer X-rays
description: Solving a puzzle Galileo struggled with, using MSG and ethanol to produce recombinant proteins, and a step closer to gentler medical imaging.

title: ASMR lullabies: The double-edged sword of digital sleepscapes
description: Millions of people are now using digital aids to help manage a growing malaise: sleep disorders. But do they stand the test of scientific rigour?

title: Why 2023 was the hottest summer yet, and a way to improve lithium-ion batteries
description: With the help of tree-ring data, scientists have found summer 2023 was the hottest thus far. Researchers have developed a new electrolyte that improves lithium-ion batteries.

title: Cats on the moon? Google AI Overview places misleading answers on top of searches
description: Mistakes by Google’s AI search tool—some funny, some harmful—make experts worried about repercussions during emergencies and in online communities.

title: How drones from Türkiye located the helicopter carrying late Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi
description: Selçuk Bayraktar, son-in-law of Turkish President Erdogan, is the brains behind the drones, which have played a key role in conflicts and rescues.

title: Cockroach: How a reviled pest from India colonised the world
description: A new study deciphers the historical routes that the most common species of cockroach took from its origins in Asia.

title: Vampire bacteria, Tarapur reactor renewal, and uncovering Fermi’s exotic particle prophecy
description: How some bacteria are attracted to blood; why scientists are extending life of Tarapur nuclear plant; and how a 1949 prediction is proven true now.

title: NASA Mars Sample Return mission to take longer than anticipated
description: CERN measures width of the W boson at the Large Hadron Collider, and scientists use spectroscopy to differentiate between space junk and asteroids.

title: With the relentless rise of AI, journalists face tough choices
description: Artificial intelligence is rapidly transforming journalism, sparking debates about innovation, transparency, and trust.

title: Cholesterol-chomping gut bacteria can reduce risk of heart attack
description: The Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument experiment has provided the largest and the most precise 3D map of the universe to date.

title: Peter Higgs (1929-2024): A fundamentally modest physicist
description: The Nobel Prize-winning physicist proposed the existence of the “God particle” that helped explain how matter formed after the Big Bang.

title: While you are asleep, your brain flushes out waste
description: Cash-strapped NASA may gradually shut down Chandra Observatory and researchers developed a device which produces high-intensity radiation.

title: How do pandemics begin?
description: From a chimpanzee research centre in the Congo to a laboratory in China, pandemics have tangled origin stories that science struggles to unravel.

title: A tool to track cell-to-cell contact
description: The Australian Synchrotron goes solar, and the Indian research satellite AstroSat detects ionising photons from a rare type of galaxy.

title: Powerful magnetic field leaves imprint on nuclear matter
description: Also, a synthetic human antibody takes us closer to a solution against snake venoms, and using light to tackle antibiotic resistance in bacteria.

title: AI chip race: Fears grow of huge financial bubble
description: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman wants a $7 trillion investment in chips—more than the US federal budget. Is it feasible?

title: Malaria vaccine trials in Africa confirm high efficacy
description: Also, Russia and India sign a new protocol for the Kudankulam plant, and the alarming news that the earth may have already crossed the 1.5°C warming level

title: What broke Paytm?
description: The rise and fall of Paytm highlights the precarious balance between ambition and compliance in the country’s financial landscape.

title: Why deepfakes are everywhere, and the fight to stop them
description: While deepfakes make distinguishing between what is real from what is cooked up almost impossible, detection remains a challenge.

title: Frontline On Air | Shooting for the stars with feet of clay
description: ISRO’s brilliant minds propelled India to space greatness, yet the Modi government lacks a clear policy for the space sector.

title: Why landing on the moon is still tough in 2024
description: NASA’s failed Artemis rocket launch is a good reminder that moon missions are as risky today as they were 60 years ago.

title: Solar panels mitigate climate change faster than forest cover
description: Also, the connection between loneliness and Parkinson’s and drones that can help rescue teams after a disaster in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: How graphene semiconductors can revolutionise electronics and computing
description: Scientists have made a breakthrough in electronics at a time when silicon, the core material from which electronics is made, is reaching its limit.

title: Shooting for the stars with feet of clay
description: ISRO’s brilliant minds propelled India to space greatness, yet the Modi government lacks a clear policy for the space sector.

title: Bridging the learning gap in Indian schools: Is generative AI the answer?
description: As advances in AI gather pace, there is a big push by the Centre and by tech firms to more firmly entrench it in education.

title: Are phones making teenagers depressed?
description: What effect does growing up in the age of smartphones and social media have on kids’ mental health? Turns out, it’s not so easy to measure.

title: Google Gemini: Is this the next big thing in AI?
description: Gemini is an AI model trained to behave in human-like ways that might intensify the debate about the technology’s potential promise and perils.

title: Could AI transform healthcare in Africa?
description: Experts say artificial intelligence could benefit African healthcare systems, but only if they are retained in the region and involve governance.

title: Do computers make children ‘dumber, not smarter’?
description: Computers have a negative influence on children’s development, say 40 researchers petitioning to stop digitisation in German schools.

title: A solar cell with unprecedented power conversion efficiency
description: Plus the inadequacy of countries’ climate action plans, and making glass-making greener in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: Sam Altman: Back at OpenAI, but questions on initial firing and future of AI persist
description: The news of his ouster had sent shockwaves throughout the AI world, raising trust concerns around the burgeoning technology.

title: Why did ChatGPT creator OpenAI oust its CEO Sam Altman?
description: The AI company’s board says Altman, the poster boy of the artificial intelligence revolution, was not candid in his communications.

title: A new climate emergency emerges in adaptation finance needs
description: The latest Adaptation Gap Report of UNEP, wasabi root increasing brain power, and more in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: Dengue rates plunge after release of lab-altered mosquitoes
description: The world sees up to 100 million cases and 22,000 deaths due to dengue every year. Researchers may have found a way to cut those numbers significantly.

title: ChatGPT to now have customised versions in bid to beat back competition
description: OpenAI says users will be able to create their own specialised versions that can help teach math to a child or explain the rules of a board game.

title: Bangladesh gets its first nuclear power plant
description: A new entrant to the nuclear club, heat-absorbing wonder material, the gravity of antimatter, and more in Science Notebook.

title: What is a ghost particle?
description: China is building the world’s largest “ghost particle” detector below the South China Sea. But what is it exactly?

title: The 2023 Nobel Prize for Medicine is a thumbs up for basic science research
description: The award for work enabling the development of the mRNA COVID-19 vaccine underscores the importance of a neglected field.

title: New brain atlases will unlock mysteries of the human mind
description: A suite of new studies unveils a detailed look at the brain and what it’s made of—a leap towards understanding brain diseases.

title: Fact check: AI doctors on social media spreading fake claims
description: Videos of AI-generated doctors giving health and beauty tips on social media are becoming popular. How accurate are their claims? Are they dangerous?

title: 2023 Laskar Award for predicting the 3D structure of proteins using AI
description: Ineffectiveness of blue light filters in glasses, carbon in Europa’s moon, and more.

title: Katalin Kariko and Drew Weissman win Nobel Prize in Medicine
description: The scientists have been awarded the Prize for work that helped in the development of mRNA vaccines.

title: OSIRIS-REx and Bennu: Sample return missions explained
description: After a seven-year round trip, NASA’s OSIRIS-REx brought asteroid samples to Earth on September 24.

title: How NASA is making autonomous rovers for the moon
description: Mini-moon rovers, how earth has seen its warmest summer yet, a solution for the “wild boar paradox”, and more in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: Rare, deadly Nipah virus: What are the symptoms?
description: The Nipah virus has once again broken out in Kerala. Those who fall ill have a low chance of survival.

title: ISRO’s Chandrayaan-3 success is only the beginning
description: India’s historic soft-landing on the moon opens new doors to lunar exploration and scientific discovery.

title: The unsung heroes behind ISRO’s successful moon landing
description: The success of Chandrayaan-3 is down to the hard work and vision of scientists who worked tirelessly after Chandrayaan-2’s failure.

title: Why you owe your life to a handful of early humans
description: Genetic analyses suggest nearly all our ancestors died in a “dramatic event” 9,00,000 years ago. Only 1,280 survived. And a bit of them is in you.

title: Karnataka’s fact-checking initiative: Will it shield democracy or stifle free speech?
description: The government’s intentions may be aimed at curbing fake news, but the move could potentially grant the state the authority to dictate the truth.

title: Chandrayaan-3 marks India’s emergence as a space power
description: The successful moon landing makes India the fourth country to achieve the feat.

title: Explained: What on Earth is dark energy?
description: Despite the leaps and bounds science has made over the course of time, there is still a lot we do not know about how everything fits together.

title: Ötzi the Iceman was darker-skinned, balder than suspected
description: The 5,000 year old mummy was mostly descended from farmers who lived in present-day Turkey, German scientists say.

title: How a photodetector will diagnose urinary infections faster
description: A fast and accurate way to diagnose urinary tract infections, a puzzling discovery about the sun, and more in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: Are we headed into climate hell? Is IPCC the one to save us?
description: Questions arise about the IPCC’s role in guiding us toward a sustainable future amid growing climate change concerns.

title: Cured of HIV, ‘Dusseldorf patient’ makes history
description: A 54-year-old man from Germany has been cured of HIV after years of treatment. In this interview he talks about his long journey to recovery.

title: Blue blood from horseshoe crabs: Valuable for medicine, but a declining bird needs them for food
description: The biomedical industry is adopting new standards to protect a primordial sea animal that is a linchpin of the production of vital medicines.

title: How science academies can enhance scientific temper in India
description: They can enhance public understanding of science through effective communication, engagement with the public and media, promoting research integrity.

title: Meet the women scientists defying harsh winters to power India’s Antarctic programme
description: India’s Antarctica programme, initiated in 1981 by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, now boasts a growing list of nearly 80 women researchers and doctors.

title: AI could help reduce cancer deaths
description: More than two million women get breast cancer every year. Early diagnosis and predicting risk with AI is helping India and Pakistan.

title: ‘Once-in-a-lifetime’ fossil shows mammal hunting dinosaur
description: One of the study’s co-authors said they believe the fossil is the first ever discovered that shows a mammal and dinosaur fighting each other.

title: Karnataka’s KC Valley project: A sustainable solution for water crisis?
description: The Koramangala-Challaghatta Valley project tackles water crisis by recharging groundwater with treated wastewater in drought-prone areas.

title: Evidence of human hand in climate change found in upper stratosphere
description: How groundwater pumping has changed the earth’s tilt, a global network to share pathogen genomics data, and more in this edition of Science Notebook.

title: Can Nasscom’s ‘Responsible AI’ guidelines pave the way for ethical and safe adoption of artificial intelligence?
description: The tech trade body wants to ensure accountability, transparency, and fairness in the application of generative AI.

title: Crystal that melts under UV light
description: As it melts, it exhibits changes in luminescence and colour.

title: China on top in research articles
description: Its contributions to articles published in the Nature Index group of high-quality natural-science journals have been increasing since 2014.

title: Non-sugar sweeteners have ill effects: WHO
description: Available evidence suggests that such sweeteners do not help reduce body fat and may lead to undesirable effects.

title: Michigan University study detects signs of activity in dying brain
description: Researchers detected intriguing brain wave patterns in four patients who passed away in hospital.

title: An extrasolar radiation belt, a la Van Allen, seen for the first time
description: It was seen using a coordinated array of 39 radio dishes from Hawaii to Germany.

title: ‘John von Neumann was ahead of his time’: Ananyo Bhattacharya
description: Ananyo Bhattacharya’s book attempts to explore one of the greatest scientific minds of the 20th century.

title: Insights into the dengue virus in India
description: It is different from the strains in other countries, which were used to make vaccines there.

title: A new platform to produce hydrogen
description: Hydrogen energy via photocatalytic production promises sustainable green energy.

title: Survivor of rare rapid-ageing disease progeria dies at 28
description: Sammy Basso, the longest living survivor of progeria, has died at 28. Progeria causes rapid aging and has a life expectancy of 13.5 years. Basso, diagnosed at two, co-founded the Italian Progeria Association and was featured in a National Geographic documentary. There are 130 recognized cases worldwide.

title: ICMR to study efficacy of Metformin, Inositol in PCOS treatment
description: ICMR will study the efficacy of Metformin and Inositol in improving fertility and birth outcomes in Indian women with PCOS. The multi-centre trial aims to fill the knowledge gap regarding these drugs' effectiveness in the Indian context, focusing on outcomes like pregnancy conception, menstrual cycle regularisation, and endocrinological improvements.

title: Should you need to worry about the asteroids hitting Earth? Understanding real challenges of asteroids grabbing attention
description: An asteroid, 2024 ON, comparable in size to the Eiffel Tower, recently captured media attention but posed no actual threat to Earth. Despite challenges in tracking Near Earth Objects (NEOs), NASA’s DART mission demonstrated a successful asteroid diversion strategy. The upcoming Hera mission aims to further refine these defense techniques.

title: PM Modi to launch Unified Genomic Chip and indigenous sex-sorted semen production tech to boost dairy farming
description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to launch the Unified Genomic Chip and indigenous sex-sorted semen production technology in Maharashtra to assist farmers in identifying high-quality cattle and producing more female calves at lower costs. Additionally, he will release the 18th instalment of Rs 20,000 crore under the PM-Kisan scheme to benefit 9.4 crore farmers.

title: Antarctica turning green 'dramatically', trend accelerated over years, study finds
description: Antarctica's vegetation cover has grown significantly, increasing from less than a square kilometre to nearly 12 square kilometres between 1986 and 2021. The accelerated greening, driven by climate change and reduced sea-ice extent, highlights the rapid and concerning transformation of the Antarctic Peninsula's landscape, emphasizing the urgent need for further research and action to protect this vulnerable region.

title: 10-m high moon replica to be erected in Guwahati to celebrate success of Chandrayaan mission
description: Guwahati will host the India International Science Festival from November 30, featuring a 10-meter high moon replica by artist Luke Jerram to celebrate the Chandrayaan mission. Organized by the Ministry of Science and Technology, this event aims to promote science achievements and discuss India's development by 2047. It includes sessions on north-east development, nuclear energy, and biotechnology's role in economic growth.

title: Seek science milestones, not personal glory: Gaganyaan astronaut; next batch selection soon: Isro Chief
description: Group Captain Angad Pratap talks about the evolving diversity in India’s human spaceflight programme, emphasizing science over personal glory. ISRO seeks candidates with expertise in experimental domains and aerospace research. The Gaganyaan training is comprehensive, covering academics, physical fitness, and survival skills, preparing astronauts for future space missions.

title: Study finds how new imaging method accurately detects kidney cancer
description: A recent study conducted by UCLA Health Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center researchers found that new, non-invasive imaging technology can detect clear-cell renal cell carcinoma, the most common kind of kidney cancer.

title: LNG's 20-year greenhouse gas footprint found to be 30% more than coal's: Study
description: LNG leaves a greenhouse gas footprint significantly higher than coal over a 20-year period, according to a new study. This footprint, driven primarily by methane emissions during extraction and liquefaction, remains equal to or worse than coal even over 100 years, challenging its label as a cleaner energy source.

title: Students from Jaffna and TN space startup collaborate to develop communication satellite
description: Students from a Sri Lankan university and SpaceKidz India are collaborating to develop a communication satellite, set to launch by ISRO in late 2025. The project aims to equip students from Jaffna and Tamil Nadu with skills in satellite technology, offering groundbreaking research opportunities and STEM education.

title: NASA to hold press conference featuring astronaut Tracy Dyson
description: NASA astronaut Tracy C. Dyson will discuss her six-month mission aboard the International Space Station on Oct. 4. Her mission highlights include remotely controlling a robot, using a 3D bioprinter for cardiac tissue, and conducting protein crystallization experiments. The event at NASA’s Johnson Space Center will be streamed live on NASA’s platforms.

title: Nasa switches off instrument on Voyager 2 spacecraft to save power
description: NASA has turned off Voyager 2's plasma science instrument to conserve power, enabling the spacecraft to continue its mission until the 2030s. Launched in 1977, Voyager 2 is over 12 billion miles from Earth and explores beyond the sun's bubble. Meanwhile, Voyager 1 continues its journey in interstellar space, over 15 billion miles from Earth.

title: Solar eclipse to create rare 'ring of fire' over South America
description: An annular solar eclipse will create a rare "ring of fire" phenomenon visible in parts of South America on Wednesday. A "ring of fire" occurs when the Moon lines up between the Sun and the Earth to create a solar eclipse, but does not block out the Sun's light entirely, Diego Hernandez with the Buenos Aires Planetarium told AFP. On Wednesday, the Moon "will be a little farther from the Earth than usual, which happens about once a month," he said, meaning it will not be able to completely cover the Sun.

title: Genetic study tracks migration history of elephants in India, finds 'dilution of diversity'
description: A genetic study reveals Indian elephants' migration from north to south over 1,00,000 years, highlighting bottlenecks that decreased genetic diversity. Researchers found five genetically distinct populations, with northern elephants being more diverse than the southern. This information aids conservation strategies for the endangered species, which constitute 60% of the global Asian elephant population.

title: Is Mount Everest, the Earth's tallest mountain still growing? What we know
description: Mount Everest's increasing height is attributed to the isostatic rebound caused by the merger of the Kosi and Arun rivers about 89,000 years ago. According to their estimates, isostatic rebound is responsible for approximately 10% of the yearly uplift rate of Everest. Isostatic rebound is a geological phenomenon that is not limited to the Himalayan region.

title: World's oldest cheese found on mummies? Scientists uncover 3,600-year-old mystery
description: Scientists have identified the oldest known cheese from the remains of Bronze Age mummies in China's Tarim Basin, dating back to around 2,000 BC. Known as kefir cheese, it was found on the heads and necks of Xiaohe people mummies. Analysis revealed it contained genetic material from cows and goats, highlighting ancient dairy practices.

title: “I hacked Nasa": Here’s why the space agency honoured a hacker’s contribution
description: An independent hacker has exposed a second breach of NASA's systems, highlighting critical vulnerabilities. After reporting the issues, NASA acknowledged the hacker’s contributions and issued an appreciation letter for responsibly identifying and helping to fix the flaws. The online community praised the hacker’s integrity and NASA's approach to rewarding security researchers.

title: Nasa astronauts receive new ride home as SpaceX Dragon capsule arrives at ISS
description: Two astronauts stuck on the ISS since June finally got their return transport through a SpaceX capsule after NASA deemed Boeing's Starliner unsafe due to thruster failures and helium leaks. The Dragon capsule will remain docked until February, while NASA continues inspecting the Starliner.

title: Earth gets a ‘mini moon’ for 2 months and it has a Mahabharata connection
description: Asteroid '2024 PT5', discovered by ATLAS in August, flew past Earth on September 29 and will orbit it for 57 days. This mini-moon, part of the Arjuna asteroid group, is closely monitored by ISRO's NETRA. It will leave Earth's orbit on November 25 and is expected to return in 2055.

title: Physical activity and beating stress are important to reduce heart diseases: Dr Raghava Sarma
description: Dr PV Raghava Sarma of Lalitha super specialty hospital highlights the urgent need for physical activity and stress management to reduce heart diseases in India. The hospital has initiated awareness activities for World Heart Day, including free screenings. He recommends a balanced diet, regular exercise, and avoiding smoking and alcohol to improve heart health.

title: Life of Indian astronaut: Gaganyaatri Angad Pratap tells about psychological, flight and survival training
description: ISRO astronaut-designate Group Captain Angad Pratap conducted his first-ever online talk on Friday. During the talk, he explained what an average day for an Indian astronaut looks like.

title: NASA to track temporary ‘mini moon’ asteroid with planetary radar — All you need to know
description: Last month, Earth acquired a temporary mini moon, 2024 PT5, detected by astronomers. NASA will monitor its path, as it orbits for nearly two months before departing in late November, with a potential return in 2055.

title: October 2024: List of celestial events to watch this month
description: October 2024 offers stargazers an array of celestial events, including the Draconid and Orionid meteor showers, an annular solar eclipse, and the full Hunter's Moon. Choose dark viewing spots, utilize binoculars, and be patient while checking weather conditions for optimal visibility.

title: Climate change impact: Antarctica is fast turning green due to extreme heat waves; here’s why it’s not a good thing
description: Antarctica's icy landscapes are turning green due to extreme heat, with vegetation increasing over tenfold in 40 years. Researchers warn this change, particularly in the Antarctic Peninsula, may harm local wildlife and alter the region's climate dynamics.

title: WHO approves first monkeypox diagnostic test for emergency use. All you need to know about EUL procedure
description: The WHO has listed the Alinity m MPXV assay for mpox testing under its Emergency Use Listing, enhancing global diagnostic capacity amid rising outbreaks. This real-time PCR test allows for quick detection of the monkeypox virus from skin lesion swabs, aiming to improve timely treatment and control.

title: Nasa to explore Jupiter's ocean world — What is Europa Clipper Mission?
description: NASA's Europa Clipper spacecraft is set to launch on October 10, 2024, to study Jupiter's moon Europa, where evidence suggests potential life-sustaining ingredients exist. The mission aims to assess the moon's ocean beneath its icy crust over six years and includes 49 flybys.

title: Sunita Williams tries on SpaceX suits for first time, all set to ride on Crew-9 ‘emergency return’ Dragon spacecraft
description: Sunita Williams return mission: The Crew 9 Dragon spacecraft is now the “emergency return spacecraft” for NASA astronauts Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore and Nick Hague, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov.

title: 5 NASA images show rich phenomena of Universe, colourful lunar features and more
description: Discoveries include a galaxy cluster with hot gas streams and star formation in the Flame Nebula, advancing our cosmic knowledge.

title: Solar eclipse 2024: Date, time of second and final Surya Grahan this year. Will it be visible in India?
description: Cosmic lovers are set to experience an exciting celestial event on October 2. The skywatchers will observe the second and final solar eclipse of 2024 on Wednesday, when the moon and sun will produce a dazzling ‘ring of fire’ in the sky visible in certain regions of the globe

title: Woman gives birth to twins from two separate uteruses; doctor calls it ‘one in a million’
description: In a remarkable case, the woman gave birth to twins from both of her uteruses, a rare occurrence with only a 0.3% prevalence. After a detailed medical plan, she delivered a healthy boy and girl, receiving widespread attention online.

title: ‘Smooth ride up here’: SpaceX Crew 9 arrives at ISS to escort Sunita Williams to Earth | Watch video
description: SpaceX Crew 9, led by Nick Hague and Aleksandr Gorbunov, arrived at the ISS and received a warm welcome from Expedition 72 crew, including Sunita Williams.

title: Hacker hacks NASA ‘again’, reports ‘vulnerabilities’; Here's what the space agency did
description: NASA praised a hacker for identifying and reporting significant security vulnerabilities. After the hacker disclosed the loopholes, he received an appreciation letter from NASA, recognizing his role in enhancing the agency's information security.

title: In a first, China unveils ‘lightweight’ moon-landing spacesuit: ‘Red stripes inspired by…’ — Key features explained
description: The design of China's moon-landing spacesuit was revealed as Xi-Jinping-led country said it plans a “manned lunar landing” by 2030.

title: Chandrayaan-3 rover lands in oldest crater where ‘no other missions have gone’; S.Vijayan says ‘shows how moon evolved'
description: Chandrayaan-3 update: The Pragyan rover captured images revealing ejecta from distant impacts and providing insights into the Moon's geological history, marking a first for this latitude

title: Crew-9 launch: SpaceX in fresh trouble? Falcon 9’s second stage ‘disposed’ outside targeted area
description: SpaceX Crew-9 launch: The second stage of SpaceX Falcon 9 safely landed in the ocean, but outside of the targeted area, Elon Musk's company said.

title: NASA's 5 never-seen-before images of Sun, stars, galaxies and stellar universe
description: NASA images: From the fiery surface of the Sun to the distant Andromeda galaxy, and the clouds of gas and dust in nebulae – these NASA images catch a glimpse of vast and vibrant universe.

title: Earth is set to get a second moon from today; here's all you need to know
description: A small asteroid named 2024 PT5 will temporarily become Earth's second moon, orbiting the planet before drifting away from its gravity.

title: SpaceX Crew-9 lifts off with Nick, Aleksandr and a ‘furry friend’ Aurora, Dragon to offer Sunita Williams ride back home
description: SpaceX Crew-9 mission launched into the space with Commander Nick Hague, Mission Specialist Aleksandr Gorbunov and a 'furry friend' Aurora on Saturday. The SpaceX Crew 9 Dragon craft will offer Sunita Williams a ride back home in February next year.

title: SpaceX Crew-9 to bring back Sunita Williams: NASA recalls 'very unusual problem' with Dragon spacecraft
description: SpaceX Crew-9 mission: The NASA shared an update on the “important” SpaceX Crew-9 mission that was earlier postponed from September 26 to September 28 in the wake of “any potential storm activity” due to Tropical Storm Helene.

title: Earth's moon to get a new friend tomorrow! How and where to see the second moon?
description: Earth's moon is all set to get a friend tomorrow for two months. An asteroid is likely to revolve around Earth till November end, hence earning the moniker ‘Earth's mini-moon’. Know how and where you can see the&nbsp;

title: Meet NASA-SpaceX Crew-9 astronauts who'll fly back with Sunita Williams: One loves sci-fi, other wanted to be biologist
description: Astronauts Nick Hague and Aleksandr Gorbuno will steer the NASA-SpaceX Crew-9 mission. While Hague has been appointed as commander of the mission, Gorbunov took the role of the mission specialist. Here's a deep dive into the roles, experience and interests of Hague and Gorbunov.

title: Just 20 seconds a day: New study reveals surprising benefits of THIS daily practice to improve mental health
description: Practising self-compassion for just 20 seconds daily can significantly enhance mental well-being. Check how to do it.

title: Mesmerizing WR 31a: NASA's latest image of Wolf-Rayet star sparks awe online; Netizens say ‘both beautiful and scary’
description: Wolf-Rayet star WR 31a, located 30,000 light-years away captivates netizens.

title: NASA is selling a brand-new Moon rover
description: Never used, one previous owner

title: 5 NASA images of Earth's undiscovered wonders: Mount Taranaki, Lake Baikal, Taieri Pet and more
description: Our planet Earth, too, has some amazing features that amaze scientists and make them wonder why this wonder exists. Check these five spectacular NASA images from Earth to stay updated with all the happenings in space.

title: Mission to 'rescue' Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore: NASA set to stream live launch of SpaceX Crew-9 — How to watch
description: NASA astronaut Nick Hague and Roscosmos cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov will launch to the International Space Station on September 28. The SpaceX Crew-9 mission launches at 1:17 pm EDT from Cape Canaveral, with live coverage starting at 9:00 am the same day.

title: ‘Sign of exciting discoveries...?’: NASA's Perseverance rover spots ‘Zebra Rock’ on Mars
description: Perseverance rover's discovery of a distinctive striped rock called 'Freya Castle' on Mars has captivated scientists and the public. The rock's unusual features indicate it may originate from a different location, fueling anticipation for future geological discoveries in the region.

title: Sahara Desert sees a surprising burst of greenery, NASA shares stunning images | Watch
description: Some regions in Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya—which barely receive a few inches of rain per year—now show traces of green after an extratropical cyclone drenched parts of northwestern Sahara on September 7 and 8. The cyclone drenched large, treeless swaths of the region.

title: ‘Strong evidence’: Breast cancer linked in food packaging; scientists raise alarm
description: A study reveals nearly 200 chemicals linked to breast cancer in food packaging and plastic tableware. Researchers urge removing these harmful substances to protect health, as 76 have been found in people. Experts call for stricter regulations and suggest alternatives to reduce exposure.

title: NASA, SpaceX delay Crew-9 mission tasked to bring back Sunita Williams – Here's why
description: NASA-SpaceX Crew 9 mission has now been scheduled for “instantaneous launch” on Saturday, September 28. There's also a backup opportunity available on Sunday.

title: Spiral galaxy 59 million light-years away looks like this: NASA shares stunning video of 'young, hot stars'
description: NASA's Hubble Space Telescope shared a stunning video of the spiral galaxy located 59 million light-years from Earth, showcasing bright blue patches indicating young stars and starburst regions where star formation is accelerated.

title: In charts: Can alternative proteins be the food of the future?
description: India’s government has come up with a new policy that will promote smart proteins that can help the country in its net-zero journey. What are smart proteins, and can India find a way to rule the global market?

title: Mpox: Kerala plans revised guidelines after India's first case of Clade 1b strain
description: The Pinarayi Vijayan government in Kerala said it will release revised guidelines for the prevention and treatment of Mpox after the state reported the first confirmed case of the new strain Clade 1b in the country on Monday

title: Chandrayaan-3 update: Pragyan rover spots 160-km-wide crater on Moon's South Pole, ‘probably formed before…’
description: India's Chandrayaan-3 mission identified a 160-km-wide crater near its landing site on the Moon's South Pole, revealing vital details about lunar geological history. The crater discovered by the Pragyan rover is located near the Aitken basin.

title: 6 NASA images of Arp 107: Why are those mysterious ‘galactic eyes’ looking at you from space?
description: The US Space Agency shared stunning images of Arp 107, a pair of colliding galaxies. Captured by the Spitzer Space Telescope, these visuals illustrate star formation and feature a supermassive black hole, emphasizing the captivating nature of interacting galaxies in space.

title: Multiple asteroids may have contributed to dinosaur extinction, scientists reveal
description: New research points to a second asteroid impact possibly contributing to the extinction of dinosaurs, challenging the long-held belief of a single impact event. This discovery comes as the European Space Agency (ESA) readies its Hera spacecraft for launch to study the results of NASA's asteroid redirection experiment from 2022. These missions aim to enhance our understanding of asteroid impacts and strengthen future planetary defense strategies in case of potential threats.

title: Is India at risk? NASA predicts strongest solar storm in seven years will hit Earth; Here’s what you should know!
description: A significant solar storm is on its way to Earth, raising alarms about potential disruptions to electronic communications and satellite operations. Dr. Annapurni Subramanian from the Indian Institute of Astrophysics, along with ISRO, is closely monitoring the situation to mitigate risks. With solar flares affecting technology, understanding the implications is crucial for both India and global systems.

title: How an 8-day trip turned into an 8-month nightmare for NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore
description: NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, initially on an eight-day mission, were stranded on the ISS for eight months due to technical issues with the Boeing Starliner. Their rescue arrived aboard a SpaceX Dragon capsule, bringing an end to their extended stay.

title: European Space Agency to send spacecraft past Mars for 'crime scene investigation'
description: The European Space Agency's Hera spacecraft is set to investigate the aftermath of NASA’s DART mission, which successfully deflected the asteroid Dimorphos. Scheduled to launch soon, Hera will analyse the impact damage and gather crucial data to better understand asteroid threats and potential planetary defences.

title: NASA is flying to Jupiter next week to find alien life hidden inside its deep oceans
description: NASA is set to launch its Europa Clipper mission on October 10, 2024, aboard a SpaceX rocket from Kennedy Space Center. This ambitious mission aims to explore Europa, Jupiter’s icy moon, which may harbor a vast ocean beneath its surface. Through nearly 50 flybys, the spacecraft will gather crucial data to assess whether Europa can support life, marking a significant step in the search for extraterrestrial life.

title: Why is NASA turning off Voyager 2’s instruments in deep space, 12 billion miles from home?
description: NASA has turned off a critical instrument on Voyager 2 to save power. This will help extend the spacecraft's mission into the 2030s. Voyager 2, launched in 1977, is now exploring interstellar space with its twin, Voyager 1. Both spacecraft continue to provide valuable scientific data.

title: NASA Asteroid Alert: Two asteroids to fly by earth today – Here's what we know
description: NASA is monitoring two asteroids, one the size of an airplane and the other like a bus, flying by Earth today. Additionally, Earth has temporarily captured a second 'moon,' a 10-meter-wide asteroid named 2024 PT5, which will orbit for 57 days.

title: Scientists discover 40 mysterious craters beneath Lake Michigan. Here's what we know so far
description: Scientists found large craters in Lake Michigan using sonar technology. The discovery was made during a mission to map the lakebed. Researchers are now focused on understanding the role these craters play in the lake’s ecosystem. They plan to explore further to learn more about their formation and significance.

title: Chandrayaan-4 to bring back 2-3 kg moon samples
description: India's Chandrayaan-4 mission, set for 2029 and costing ₹2,104.06 crore, plans to return lunar surface samples. The mission will utilize five modules launched on two LVM3 vehicles. Key technologies, developed domestically, aim to advance skill development, create jobs, and drive technological progress.

title: Chandrayaan-3 landed within a buried, one of the oldest craters on Moon: PRL-ISRO study
description: Chandrayaan-3's Pragyan rover and Vikram lander have landed in an ancient, buried impact crater approximately 160 km in diameter and 4.4 km deep, near the south pole of the Moon. This location holds significant geological history, including materials from the South Pole Atkin basin.

title: Scientists found a massive underground ocean hidden 700km below Earth's surface. Here's all about it
description: Scientists have unearthed a massive underground ocean located 700 kilometers beneath Earth’s surface, found within ringwoodite’s crystalline structure. This hidden ocean, thrice the size of our surface oceans, may revolutionize our comprehension of Earth’s water cycle. Researchers used seismic data from earthquakes to identify these water-rich rocks, with further studies planned to understand its global impact.

title: Is Mount Everest still rising? The surprising truth behind its growth
description: Mount Everest continues to grow in height due to isostatic rebound, a process linked to the merger of the Kosi and Arun rivers about 89,000 years ago. This merger caused significant erosion, reducing land weight and increasing the mountain's elevation by an estimated 49-164 feet.

title: SpaceX capsule docks at ISS: NASA's Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore set for 2025 return
description: A SpaceX capsule has docked at the ISS to bring back NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore, stranded due to Boeing Starliner issues. They are set to return in 2024 aboard SpaceX’s Crew-9 mission.

title: SpaceX Crew Dragon space capsule docks at ISS to rescue astronaut Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore
Why Elon Musk's plan to colonize Mars may be a bad idea: Humans can turn green and go blind on the red planet
description: Colonizing Mars presents significant challenges, according to experts. Dr. Scott Solomon warns that the planet's harsh conditions could lead to mutations in children born there, including changes in skin color, weakened bones, and impaired eyesight. NASA plans to send humans to Mars by the 2030s, while SpaceX envisions a city on the planet within 30 years. Addressing these issues is crucial for the future of human settlement on Mars.

title: NASA hacker strikes again, exposes major security flaw; Here's how the space agency responded
description: Nasa Website Hacked: A hacker has claimed to have infiltrated NASA's systems, exposing security vulnerabilities. The hacker reported these issues to NASA, which acknowledged the effort with an official letter of appreciation. This incident highlights the importance of ethical hackers in securing sensitive systems and has sparked discussions on social media about their role.

title: How staying home during Covid lockdown cooled down the Moon's temperature by around -250 degrees, says new study
description: Moon Temperature: Indian researchers have discovered a link between the global Covid-19 lockdowns of 2020 and a decrease in the Moon's night-time surface temperatures. Using data from NASA's Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter, they found an 8-10 Kelvin drop in moon temperatures, attributed to reduced Earth's outgoing radiation during the lockdown period.

title: Stuck NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore welcome SpaceX capsule that'll bring them home next year
description: Two astronauts at the International Space Station since June received a new ride home with the arrival of a SpaceX capsule. NASA switched Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams to SpaceX due to safety concerns with their Boeing Starliner capsule. The Dragon capsule will stay until February, extending their mission to over eight months.

title: Earth getting a mini-moon tonight. Here's how you can see it
description: Earth will gain a temporary mini-moon tonight as asteroid 2024 PT5, about 33 feet wide, orbits the planet until November 25. Discovered by NASA's Atlas on August 7, it will not be visible to the naked eye but can be captured by professional telescopes. The asteroid is expected to return in 2055.

title: Earth's second mini-moon 2024 PT5 to be visible from today: Here's what you need to know about it
description: Earth will briefly host a new visitor, asteroid 2024 PT5, from September 29 to November 25. Originating from the Arjuna asteroid belt, this mini-moon was detected by NASA in August. Although it won't be visible to the naked eye, professional telescopes will capture images of its journey past the stars.

title: Chandrayaan-3 landed on a 3.85 bn-year-old lunar crater, says researcher
description: India's Chandrayaan-3 mission has possibly landed in one of the Moon's oldest craters, dating back 3.85 billion years. Images from the Pragyan rover and satellites reveal unique geological features at the landing site, offering insights into the Moon's evolution. The site, named Shiv Shakti Point, contains material from various lunar regions.

title: NASA SpaceX Crew-9 soars: Nick, Aleksandr, and a furry co-pilot take off to bring Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore back
description: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-9 mission successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, marking the first human spaceflight from pad 40. The crew, including NASA astronaut Nick Hague and Roscosmos cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov, is en route to the ISS with a Zero-G indicator named Aurora. They are expected to dock on Sunday evening.

title: SpaceX launches rescue mission for stranded NASA astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore
description: SpaceX launched a mission to rescue two astronauts stranded at the International Space Station. The capsule will bring them back in February after their Boeing spacecraft returned empty due to safety concerns. NASA's Nick Hague and Russia's Alexander Gorbunov are leading the mission, which highlights ongoing challenges in space travel.

title: Australian scientist confirm 100-year-old theory, discover  new cell type that can heal chronic injuries
description: Scientists from SAHMRI and the University of Adelaide have discovered a new cell type called EndoMac progenitors. These cells, found in the aortas of adult mice, can transform into blood vessel and immune cells. This discovery could lead to new treatments for chronic conditions like diabetes by improving healing processes.

title: NASA SpaceX Crew-9 launch details: When, where to watch live stream as Sunita Williams, Butch Wilmore make their way to Earth
description: Nasa will launch the SpaceX Crew-9 mission on Saturday, bringing astronauts Sunita Williams and Butch Wilmore back to Earth after their extended stay on the ISS. The mission includes Nasa astronaut Nick Hague and Roscosmos cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov. Originally delayed due to Hurricane Helene, the launch is now set for September 28.

title: Orionid meteor shower from Halley's Comet starts: Here is how, where, and when to watch the annual cosmic event
description: The Orionids meteor shower, caused by debris from Halley's Comet, begins on September 26 and runs through November 22. The peak night is expected between October 20 and October 21. Observers are advised to find dark skies away from urban light pollution for the best viewing experience.

title: Scientists discover exoplanet that may offer a glimpse into earth's fate
description: Scientists have discovered an Earth-like planet orbiting a white dwarf star, providing insights into the future of our Solar System. The planet, about 1.9 times the mass of Earth, was likely pushed further out during the star's red giant phase. This discovery hints that Earth could survive the Sun’s red giant phase.

title: NASA finds a mysterious Zebra rock on Mars: Here's all about this new exciting discovery
description: NASA's Perseverance Rover has discovered a unique 'zebra rock' in Mars' Jezero Crater, characterized by black-and-white stripes. The rock, named 'Freya Castle,' is unlike any seen before on Mars and may have rolled downhill from a higher source. This discovery could lead to more exciting findings as the rover continues its mission.

title: One in two El Nino events could be extreme by 2050, study finds
description: A new study predicts that by 2050, one in every two El Nino events could be extreme if greenhouse gas emissions continue at current rates. This could lead to more frequent and intense weather events, impacting life and property. The study used computer models and fossil data to validate its findings.

title: Can X-rays, used for broken bones, be NASA's secret weapon to help save Earth from killer asteroids? Here's what scientists say
description: Scientists at Sandia National Laboratories have made significant strides in understanding how nuclear explosions could be employed to deflect dangerous asteroids. Through laboratory experiments simulating nuclear blasts using X-rays on a mock asteroid, the research demonstrates the viability of this approach. With recent advancements in planetary defense, such as NASA's DART mission, this study underscores the importance of preparedness against potential asteroid impacts in the future.

title: Though it's not the moon yet, it's the next best thing for European astronauts
description: The European Space Agency has opened the LUNA facility in Germany to simulate lunar conditions for astronaut training. The facility features ground-up volcanic rock and movable trolleys to mimic the moon's surface and low gravity. ESA aims to prepare astronauts for future moon missions under NASA's Artemis program by 2030.

title: Earth to encounter this fuzzy-star like comet after 80,000 years. Here's when and how to watch this rare cosmic event
description: Comet C/2023 A3, also known as Tsuchinshan-ATLAS, will be visible in the early morning hours from Friday through Monday. The comet, which last appeared 80,000 years ago, will look like a faint star with a hazy tail. It is expected to shine brightly by the end of September 2024.

title: SpaceX Crew Dragon mission: Obectives, launch date & time, and how to watch it live online
description: NASA is preparing for the SpaceX Crew-9 mission to the International Space Station, now set for September 28 due to Tropical Storm Helene. The mission will send three NASA astronauts and a Russian cosmonaut to the ISS and bring back two astronauts stranded due to issues with Boeing's Starliner spacecraft.

title: Indian-origin techie develops AI that not only captures every moment of your life but also tells you what to focus on
description: Advait Paliwal, an Indian-origin entrepreneur, has introduced Iris, an AI wearable device that captures life moments by taking pictures every minute. The device uses AI to organize and caption these images, helping users remember details. While it offers benefits for health and safety, privacy concerns have been raised.

title: 200-year-old message in a bottle left by archaeologist unearthed in France
description: Volunteers have discovered a 200-year-old message in a bottle at an excavation site in Normandy, France. The letter, left by archaeologist P.J Féret in 1825, provides details about the ancient Gaulish clifftop village near Eu. The discovery was unexpected and offers new insights into past excavations at the site.

title: Antarctica's ‘doomsday glacier’ nearing collapse, scientists warn it's happening sooner than expected
description: Scientists have discovered that Antarctica's Thwaites Glacier is melting rapidly and may be on an irreversible path to collapse, potentially causing catastrophic global sea level rise. Their six-year study revealed unexpected melting patterns and the significant impact of warm ocean water. Immediate action is required to mitigate these effects.

title: Untreatable fungal infections are now killing nearly 3.8 mn each year, WHO experts sound alarm
description: Deadly Fungal Infection: The world faces a growing crisis in antifungal resistance, with fungal infections causing millions of deaths annually. Researchers urge global health discussions to include this issue, as fungi are becoming resistant to current treatments. The upcoming UN meeting on antimicrobial resistance is seen as crucial for addressing this silent pandemic.

title: NASA’s Chandra X-ray observatory telescope identifies galaxy’s black hole delivery system, dubbed Nikhuli
description: NASA's Chandra X-ray Observatory and Hubble Space Telescope have identified a galaxy's black hole delivery system named 'Nikhuli,' after a term from the Sumi community in Nagaland. The study suggests that Nikhuli, a cluster of stars, is delivering a massive black hole to the spiral galaxy NGC 4424, located 54 million light-years from Earth.

title: Capsule carrying 2 Russians, 1 American returns to Earth from space station
description: A Soyuz capsule carrying two Russian astronauts, Oleg Kononenko and Nikolai Chub, and American astronaut Tracy Dyson successfully landed in Kazakhstan after undocking from the International Space Station.

title: Five Asteroids to Fear: NASA warns of space rocks with one packing firepower of nearly 5 mn Hiroshima bombs!
description: Asteroid Alert: NASA actively monitors asteroids that could potentially threaten Earth. The most concerning is Bennu, which has a 1 in 2,700 chance of impacting in 2182, potentially causing significant casualties. Other notable asteroids include 29075 (1950 DA) and 2023 TL4, with impact chances projected centuries away. Although all monitored asteroids are currently rated as zero risk, continuous vigilance is essential to ensure planetary safety.

title: Chandrayaan-3 discovers ancient 160-km crater on Moon, sheds new light on lunar history
description: India's Chandrayaan-3 mission has identified a 160-km-wide crater near its landing site on the Moon. The discovery, made by the Pragyan rover, provides crucial insights into the Moon's early geological evolution. This ancient crater, older than the Aitken basin, offers a rare opportunity to study one of the earliest lunar formations.

title: Elon Musk announces new missions to Mars, says 'everybody may visit the red planet soon'
description: SpaceX plans to launch five uncrewed Starship missions to Mars over the next two years, aligning with the upcoming Earth-Mars transfer window. CEO Elon Musk announced that these missions aim to pave the way for future crewed flights, potentially starting in four years if successful.

title: Scientists discover 120-million-year-old Earth section: Here's how it could change what we know about our planet
description: Geologists have uncovered a long-lost tectonic plate called Pontus, believed to have existed 120 million years ago in Borneo. Led by Suzanna van de Lagemaat from Utrecht University, the discovery reveals new information about Earth’s geological past and the breakup of Pangaea. This breakthrough, based on magnetic data from ancient rock formations, offers insights into how tectonic plates shaped modern-day regions like Borneo and the Philippines.

title: China startup's kerosene-powered rocket fails test flight
description: China's Deep Blue Aerospace announced that its reusable kerosene-fuelled rocket, Nebula-1, failed to complete a high-altitude vertical recovery test flight in Inner Mongolia. The rocket successfully completed 10 out of 11 tasks but crashed during the final stage due to a landing system failure, causing significant damage.

title: NASA planning to send an artificial 'star' to space. Here's all about the mission
description: NASA plans to launch an artificial star by 2029 to help scientists calibrate telescopes and improve measurements of stellar brightness. This $19.5 million mission, led by George Mason University, aims to enhance our understanding of the universe's expansion and refine dark energy parameters, potentially leading to significant scientific breakthroughs.

title: Two asteroids, including a massive 120-foot one, to fly past Earth on Sept 24. NASA says this
description: Nasa Asteroids: Two asteroids will pass by Earth on September 24, 2024. One of them, Asteroid 2024 RO11, is notable for its size of 120 feet and will come within 4,580,000 miles of Earth. The smaller Asteroid 2020 GE, measuring 26 feet in diameter, will pass at a distance of approximately 410,000 miles.

title: Scientist links human consciousness to a higher dimension beyond our perception
description: Physicist Michael Pravica proposes a controversial theory suggesting that human consciousness connects to hidden dimensions beyond our perception. He argues that in moments of heightened awareness, such as creativity or dreaming, consciousness may access these higher planes. While the theory has sparked interest, it faces skepticism within the scientific community regarding its implications and validity.

title: NASA releases chilling, eerie black hole audio from 250 million light years away
description: NASA has released an audio clip capturing sound waves from a supermassive black hole located 250 million light years away in the Perseus galaxy cluster. The waves were transposed up 57 and 58 octaves to make them audible to human ears, revealing eerie sounds that provide insights into intergalactic space.

title: Elon Musk calls for accountability, says 'FAA should fine Boeing, not SpaceX, for stranding astronauts in Space'
description: Elon Musk has criticised the FAA for fining SpaceX over licensing violations while ignoring safety issues at Boeing. The FAA fined SpaceX $633,009 for using an unauthorised launch control room and previously fined them for not submitting safety information. Musk argues that the FAA's actions jeopardise human lives and hinder innovation.

title: ISRO, IN-SPACe & NSIL sign five tech transfer pact with non-governmental entities
description: ISRO, IN-SPACe, and NSIL have signed five Technology Transfer Agreements with private companies, marking a total of 75 agreements since space reforms. This milestone aims to empower India's private sector to utilize advanced space technologies for commercial and societal applications. The agreements were signed with Anabond Ltd, Salvo Industries Pvt Ltd, Micropack Pvt Ltd, and Astra Microwave Products Ltd.

title: 8 of the Most Celebrated Awards in Science Outside of Nobel Prizes
description: The Nobel Foundation offers prizes in only three disciplines, but other awards have been created to honor scientists in different fields.

title: Researchers Find Cannibalized Victim of 19th-Century Arctic Voyage
description: A new study offers clues to a 179-year-old mystery that killed more than 100 explorers on the Franklin expedition in the Canadian Arctic.

title: Scientists Found a Surprising Way to Make Fungus Happy
description: The discovery that sound improves the growth rate of beneficial fungus suggests that dirges in the dirt may help restore forests.

title: Ex-OceanGate Employee’s Remarks Hint at Titan Disaster Lawsuits to Come
description: A former Coast Guard specialist’s testimony capped two weeks of hearings into the implosion of a submersible that killed five during an attempt to explore the Titanic.

title: The Oldest Termite Mound? 34,000 Years and Counting.
description: Scientists recently found the planet’s longest continuously occupied termite colony in an arid region of South Africa. It dates to the time of the Neanderthals.

title: DNA Reveals the Origin Stories of America’s Captive Tigers
description: Scientists have wondered if the many captive tigers in the United States could one day help restore the species in the wild.

title: The Food of Space Travel Could Be Based on Rocks
description: Scientists are studying whether future astronauts on deep-space journeys could transform compounds in asteroids into food.

title: After a Decade, Scientists Unveil Fly Brain in Stunning Detail
description: Scientists have mapped out how 140,000 neurons are wired in the brain of the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster.

title: Iran Would Need Much More Than Weeks to Build a Nuclear Bomb
description: Nuclear experts see Tehran as facing up to a year of hard work to master the knotty basics of building a deliverable atom bomb.

title: The Problem With the Hurricane Category Rating
description: After Helene, it may be time to rethink how to communicate the risks posed by storms, especially extreme rain.

title: Rwanda’s Doctors and Nurses Hit Hard by Deadly Marburg Virus
description: The Health Ministry has reported that 80 percent of the infected are health care professionals.

title: As Bird Flu Spreads, Two New Cases Diagnosed in California
description: Both patients were dairy workers whose illnesses were mild. Investigators are continuing to evaluate the contacts of a Missouri patient who had no exposure to animals.

title: What to Know About the 2024 Nobel Prizes
description: The annual prizes will be announced beginning Monday.

title: Nighttime Depression Is a Real Thing
description: There are lots of reasons your mood might tank at night. Here’s how to address the bedtime blues.

title: What to Know About Test Alternatives to Colonoscopies for Colon Cancer Screening
description: Doctors can provide alternative forms of screening for colon and rectal cancer but sometimes have a good reason to stick with the colonoscope.

title: A NOAA Climate Agency in Asheville Was Knocked Out by Helene
description: The National Centers for Environmental Information in Asheville, N.C., sweep together data from around the world to help track Earth’s warming.

title: Trump Promised to Release His Medical Records. He Still Won’t Do It.
description: If elected again, he would become the oldest president by the end of his term. Yet he is refusing to disclose even basic health information.

title: Gilead Agrees to Allow Generic Version of Groundbreaking H.I.V. Shot in Poor Countries
description: Many middle-income countries are left out of the deal, widening a gulf in access to critical medicines.

title: Officials Cast Doubt on a Dementia Drug, but Human Trials Continue
description: The S.E.C. alleged shortcomings in research said to support the drug, and its developer agreed to a $40 million settlement. Some experts wonder why clinical trials have not been stopped.

title: How the VP Candidates Talked About Climate Change
description: Tim Walz said climate change is real, but boasted about high U.S. levels of oil and gas production. JD Vance called climate change “weird science.”

title: Hurricane Helene Deaths Will Continue for Years, Study Suggests
description: Research on hundreds of tropical storms finds that mortality keeps rising for more than a decade afterward, for reasons you might not expect.

title: ‘Ring of Fire’ Solar Eclipse Will Be Visible in Parts of South America
description: Not everyone will be able to see the phenomenon, known as an annular eclipse, on Wednesday, though a partial solar eclipse may be visible in parts of Antarctica and Hawaii.

title: You Can Stand Under My Umbrella, if You’re an Egg-Laying Locust
description: Male locusts have long been observed shielding mates from other males. Researchers say this behavior may also protect the females from desert temperatures.

title: Why Restoring Power After Hurricane Helene Is Complicated
description: Damage went beyond downed power lines. Hundreds of substations went out after the storm. Getting them back online is difficult.

title: Breast Cancer Continues to Rise Among Younger Women, Study Finds
description: Death rates are declining among U.S. women with breast cancer. But the disease is turning up more often in women under age 50.

title: Wreck of ‘Ghost Ship of the Pacific’ Found Off California
description: The rediscovery of the vessel, which was captured by the Japanese for a time during World War II, highlights the potential of underwater autonomous vehicles to map the ocean floor.

title: Why Helene Was So Destructive in Florida, the Carolinas and Appalachia
description: Hurricanes typically weaken over land. But if the ground is already wet from earlier rains, storms can receive an extra jolt that keeps them churning.

title: California Sues Hospital for Denying Patient an Emergency Abortion
description: The state said that despite a doctor’s recommendation and state law, a Catholic hospital declined to provide an abortion because fetal heart tones were present.

title: Why Mount Everest Is Growing Taller Every Year
description: Researchers say that two rivers merged some 89,000 years ago and gave the mightiest peak in the Himalayas a huge growth spurt.

title: Britain Shuts Down Last Coal Plant, ‘Turning Its Back on Coal Forever’
description: The Ratcliffe-on-Soar plant was the last surviving coal-burning power station in a country that birthed the Industrial Revolution and fed it with coal.

title: Northern Lights possible as solar storms gather
description: The largest solar flare since 2017 has been spotted erupting from the Sun’s surface.

title: The asteroid that killed the dinosaurs was not alone
description: A second asteroid hit Earth around the same time causing a "catastrophic" event.

title: Fly brain breakthrough 'huge leap' to unlock human mind
description: A new map showing 50 million neural connections is a 'huge leap' to understanding our own brains.

title: Rare brightening comet seen passing Earth from Hawaii
description: Scientists estimate the last time Comet Tsuchinshan-ATLAS visited our solar system was 80,000 years ago.

title: UK to finish with coal power after 142 years
description: The UK's last coal power station, Ratcliffe-on-Soar, is due to end operations on Monday.

title: SpaceX docks at ISS to collect stranded astronauts
description: The craft will return Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams - stranded since June - to Earth.

title: An 'abomination' of a sub – and the boss convinced Titan was safe
description: A damning picture emerges from a public hearing into the failure of Oceangate’s Titan submersible.

title: Climate change supercharged Europe floods - scientists
description: A new study shows that the record-breaking rainfall was made more likely and intense by climate change.

title: Sir David Attenborough: 'The world would be worse off without our stories'
description: Sir David Attenborough praises the "beauty" created by the BBC in its natural history shows.

title: Titan sub disaster: Five key questions that remain
description: A public hearing is set to examine the events surrounding the catastrophic failure of Oceangate’s submersible.

title: Mystery tremors were from massive nine-day tsunami
description: Scientists launched an investigation after being baffled by seismic signals picked up across the world

title: The great gene editing debate: can it be safe and ethical?
description: A UK law allowing gene-edited food has been paused and some British scientists fear being overtaken.

title: Which rural area will take the UK’s nuclear waste?
description: The UK's nuclear waste needs a permanent home - but finding a community willing to take it is tricky.

title: Anti-pollution law to threaten water bosses with jail
description: New legislation gives regulators more powers to tackle water pollution in England and Wales.

title: Striking images reveal depths of Titanic's slow decay
description: A new expedition finds that a large part of the railing at the ship's front has fallen away.

title: Badger culling to end in England within five years
description: Efforts to stop the spread of bovine tuberculosis will now focus on vaccinating badgers not killing them.

title: Baby boom prompts call to boost wild beaver population
description: A leading conservation group wants the government to give the go-ahead to bringing back beavers in the wild.

title: Why the skies turned red over the UK this weekend
description: Smoke from wildfires in north America has brought a "vivid" hue to skies above Britain ahead of a rare lunar phenomenon.

title: Brian May argues for better farm hygiene to protect badgers
description: The Queen guitarist has led a 10-year study to combat bovine TB spread and help end badger culling.

title: UK military satellite launches to boost space power
description: British forces are about to get their first dedicated surveillance and reconnaissance satellite.

title: Scottish isles may solve mystery of 'Snowball Earth'
description: The islands could reveal why animal life first emerged on our planet after its biggest ever freeze.

title: Watch: The Northern Lights seen from space
description: A timelapse captured from the International Space Station shows the Moon setting into streams of aurora.

title: 400-year record heat threat to Great Barrier Reef
description: The highest sea temperatures in 400 years could threaten the reef's survival, say scientists.

title: Water firms to be punished for years of sewage leaks
description: Thames Water, Northumbrian Water and Yorkshire Water face fines for repeated sewage leaks.

title: Witness to Titan sub tragedy tells of fear and false hope
description: Rory Golden, who was on the Titan sub's support ship when it went missing, recounts the experience.

title: World's biggest iceberg spins in ocean trap
description: A frozen block of ice far bigger than Greater London is captured in a vast pool of rotating water.

title: Famous Stonehenge stone came from Scotland not Wales
description: Stonehenge's famous Altar Stone came from Scotland not Wales as previously thought, new analysis shows.

title: Joyful welcome by stranded astronauts for SpaceX capsule crew
description: A capsule sent to bring back two astronauts stranded on the International Space Station has docked.

title: Astronauts reveal what life is like on ISS – and how they deal with 'space smell'
description: As Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore spend months longer than planned on ISS, three astronauts tell us what life is like in orbit.

title: Reservoir of liquid water found deep in Martian rocks
description: Studies of quakes detected from the planet's surface found it in the planet's rocky outer crust.

title: Europe's Ariane-6 rocket blasts off on maiden flight
description: After a successful launch, the upper-stage of the rocket goes on to experience an anomaly.

title: Satellite captures first-of-a-kind cloud image
description: A joint European-Japanese mission captures a space view of the internal structure of a cloud.

title: Musk's SpaceX to destroy retired space station
description: The California-based company will build a "tugboat" to execute the end-of-life disposal of the ISS.

title: Who owns the Moon? A new space race means it could be up for grabs
description: A race for the lunar surface's resources is currently under way. What’s to stop a Wild West opening up?

title: Study reveals role of gamma-delta T cells in cancer immunology
description: A study published in Cell Press reveals the significant role of gamma-delta T cells in treatment outcomes for 33 cancer types. Researchers at Moffitt Cancer Center found that these cells' diversity and clonality impact patient survival and treatment efficacy, providing new clinical biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

title: Eyes on moon: National space panel clears India’s 5th lunar mission Lupex; lander engine to be used to land humans on moon
description: India's lunar ambitions are advancing with the clearance of the fifth lunar mission, Lupex, to be jointly implemented by India and Japan. This mission, following Chandrayaan-1 to 4, aims to explore the Moon for water and resources, and marks a step towards India's goal of human lunar landing.

title: Scientists grow lost 'biblical tree' from 1,000-year-old seed
description: Archaeologists discovered a 1,000-year-old seed in the Judean desert, which grew into a 10-foot tree believed to be linked to biblical trees. Despite thriving, the tree did not produce aromatic compounds like myrrh. Research was published after confirming its distinct identity from Judean Balsam.

title: Weather may delay launch of mission to study deflected asteroid
description: Stormy weather might postpone the launch of Europe's Hera spacecraft, aimed at analyzing the aftermath of NASA's DART collision with the asteroid Dimorphos. Scheduled for Monday, the mission's objective is to gather crucial data on planetary defense. If postponed, a back-up launch is set for Tuesday. The launch window extends until October 27.

title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine: Who are Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun?
description: The 2024 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine has been awarded to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for their discovery of microRNA and its role in post-transcriptional gene regulation. This groundbreaking work has revealed a new principle of gene regulation essential for multicellular organisms, including humans, with the human genome coding for over a thousand microRNAs.

title: Nobel Prize 2024 in Medicine goes to Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun for discovery of microRNA
description: Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun have been awarded the 2024 Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine for their discovery of microRNA and its role in post-transcriptional gene regulation. The prize follows the 2023 award to Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman for groundbreaking mRNA vaccine research.

title: Asteroid may become new wonder-food for astronauts, claims new study
description: A study published in The International Journal of Astrobiology reveals a groundbreaking concept where astronauts could use asteroids to meet their nutritional needs. While the carbon from asteroids may be transformed into edible biomass, extensive testing is still required to ensure its safety. This new approach offers hope for addressing the challenge of food scarcity during long-duration space missions, though significant hurdles remain before it can be realized.

title: Hera to Launch in Florida on SpaceX Rocket: How to Watch
description: The Hera spacecraft, expected to take flight Monday morning, is part of a broader effort to bolster humanity’s planetary defense readiness.

title: How Can I Cut PFAS ‘Forever Chemicals?’
description: They’re almost everywhere. And they’re bad. But there are some things you can do to avoid them.

title: The Nobel Prizes: What is the point?
description: Dubbed the “Mount Everest of science”, the Prize faces criticism for how it chooses winners. Is it relevant in an era of global research?

title: Why India needs a museum for its fossils
description: We are losing invaluable palaeontological history because we have neither a legal framework nor the awareness to protect fossils.

title: SpaceX launches European Asteroid mission Hera into sky from Florida despite approaching hurricane Milton
description: European Space Agency (ESA) on Monday said the Hera mission lifted off on a SpaceX Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida at 10:52 local time (14:52 UTC).

title: A spacecraft is on its way to a harmless asteroid slammed by NASA in a previous save-the-Earth test
description: The European Space Agency's Hera spacecraft, launched by SpaceX, is embarking on a mission to examine the asteroid Dimorphos, which was impacted by NASA's Dart to test planetary defense. Hera will gather detailed scientific data to evaluate the effectiveness of the deflection and inform future strategies for protecting Earth.

title: NGLV development model will be announced soon: ISRO chief S Somnath
description: The ISRO chief announced that the model for the Next Generation Launch Vehicle (NGLV) will be revealed soon. This move will allow extensive industry participation from the design phase. The Union Cabinet has approved NGLV's development, aiming for operations at the Bharatiya Antariksh Station and an Indian crewed Moon landing by 2040.

title: What is daylight saving time after which US citizens get an extra hour of sleep? Explained
description: Daylight saving time, affecting North America, is under scrutiny due to recent legislative proposals and public sentiment. People will soon get an extra hour of sleep as clocks move back in November. The practice, which was first adopted by Germany in 1916, sees various debates including energy savings and potential health risks.

title: What is microRNA? All about Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun's discovery which won them Nobel Prize in Medicine 2024
description: Scientists Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun won the 2024 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for discovering microRNA and its role in gene regulation. This pivotal finding has clarified how organisms develop and function, with microRNAs playing a critical part in maintaining normal cellular functions and being linked to diseases such as cancer.

title: When Two Sea Aliens Become One
description: Primitive animals called comb jellies can fuse their bodies and nervous systems together.

title: Spacecraft launches towards asteroid knocked off course by Nasa
description: The mission aims to re-visit the asteroid Nasa diverted when it crashed a probe into it.

title: My pilgrimage to the vanishing Sphinx snow patch
description: The Sphinx, a patch of snow thought to be the longest-lasting in the UK, has melted for the fourth consecutive year.

title: Nobel Prize goes to microRNA researchers
description: US scientists Victor Ambros and Gary Ruvkun helped explain how genes work inside the human body.
